notes.title: Vector Calculus & Differential Operators
notes.content:
Master the fundamental concepts of vector calculus essential for CSS Applied Mathematics. This includes gradient, divergence, and curl operations in various coordinate systems.

Key theorems include Green's theorem for line integrals, Stokes' theorem for surface integrals, and the divergence theorem (Gauss's theorem) for volume integrals.

CSS-specific emphasis includes: Green's theorem region problems (e.g., regions bounded by y = x and y = x²), Stokes' theorem verification, divergence calculations over cylinders and planes, and curvilinear coordinate identities like ∇(rⁿ) and ∇·[f(r) r̂].

Practice converting between Cartesian, cylindrical, and spherical coordinate systems, as CSS exams frequently test these transformations.
keyTakeaways: Practice CSS past paper problems (e.g., Green's theorem over y = x and y = x²).
Memorize standard curvilinear coordinate formulas (cylindrical and spherical).
Proof skeletons for theorems: link curl circulation to surface integrals.

notes.title: Differential Equations (ODE/PDE/Fourier)
notes.content:
Comprehensive coverage of differential equations as tested in CSS Applied Mathematics. This includes both ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and partial differential equations (PDEs).

ODE methods include: variation of parameters, Bernoulli equations, Riccati equations, series solutions using Frobenius method, and special functions like Bessel and Legendre.

PDE topics cover: classification of PDEs, separation of variables technique, heat equation, wave equation, and Laplace equation solutions using Fourier series.

CSS exams emphasize practical problem-solving over theoretical proofs. Focus on recognizing equation types and selecting appropriate solution methods quickly.
keyTakeaways: Memorize table of RHS vs Particular Integral.
Practice series method on CSS sample questions (e.g. 2024 Q2b).
Have Fourier expansions at your fingertips for essay-level PDEs.

notes.title: Mechanics, Kinematics & Dynamics
notes.content:
Classical mechanics forms a significant portion of CSS Applied Mathematics. Topics include particle dynamics, rigid body motion, and orbital mechanics.

Key areas cover: center of mass calculations for standard shapes (cone, sphere, hemisphere), simple harmonic motion in various forms, radial and transverse components of velocity and acceleration, and central force problems.

Orbital mechanics includes: Kepler's laws, areal velocity, Binet's formula for deriving force laws from orbital equations r(θ), and energy considerations in conservative force fields.

CSS questions often combine mechanics with vector calculus, requiring clear understanding of both domains.
keyTakeaways: Learn how CSS frames COM and SHM questions; practice 2019/2020 examples.
Use Binet's formula for proving force laws from r(θ).
Emphasize conceptual clarity (energy, torque) for derivation parts.

notes.title: Tensor Analysis & Curvilinear Coordinates
notes.content:
Tensor analysis provides the mathematical framework for expressing physical laws in coordinate-independent form. Essential for advanced mechanics and field theory.

Topics include: covariant and contravariant components, metric tensor, Christoffel symbols, and tensor transformations. Applications in curvilinear coordinates are emphasized.

CSS focus areas: converting between coordinate systems, calculating scale factors, expressing differential operators in cylindrical and spherical coordinates, and solving problems involving non-Cartesian geometries.

While pure tensor notation questions are rare, understanding curvilinear coordinates is essential for vector calculus problems.
keyTakeaways: Master coordinate transformations and scale factors.
Practice expressing grad, div, curl in cylindrical/spherical coordinates.
Understand metric tensor basics for coordinate system problems.

notes.title: Numerical Methods
notes.content:
Numerical analysis techniques for solving mathematical problems computationally. CSS emphasizes practical algorithms over theoretical convergence proofs.

Root finding methods: Newton-Raphson, bisection, and fixed-point iteration. System solving: Jacobi and Gauss-Seidel iterative methods with convergence conditions (diagonal dominance).

Interpolation techniques: Newton's forward/backward differences, Lagrange interpolation, and Gauss interpolation formulas. Numerical integration: trapezoidal rule, Simpson's 1/3 and 3/8 rules with error estimates.

Numerical solutions of ODEs: Euler's method, modified Euler, and Runge-Kutta methods (2nd and 4th order). Always state truncation errors and stability conditions.
keyTakeaways: Always state convergence conditions (dominant diagonal).
Show truncation error for Simpson/Trapezoid.
Keep clear format of method steps (iterate, stop criteria).

notes.title: Multiple & Line/Surface Integrals
notes.content:
Integration techniques in multiple dimensions form the computational backbone of vector calculus applications. CSS tests both setup and evaluation skills.

Double and triple integrals: setting up limits in Cartesian and polar coordinates, changing order of integration, and Jacobian transformations for general coordinate changes.

Line integrals: parametrization of curves (including piecewise smooth paths), work integrals, and circulation. Surface integrals: parametric surfaces, flux calculations, and orientation considerations.

CSS emphasis: Always sketch the region/curve/surface, clearly show parametrization, and verify differential elements (dA, ds, normal vectors).
keyTakeaways: Always sketch region; parameterize path/surface clearly.
Double-check differential elements (dA, ds, n-vector).

notes.title: Linear Algebra & Matrix Methods
notes.content:
Matrix methods provide efficient tools for solving systems of equations and analyzing linear transformations. CSS focuses on computational aspects.

Key topics: matrix operations, determinants (especially 3×3 using cofactor expansion), inverse matrices using adjugate method, and solving linear systems.

Eigenvalue problems: characteristic polynomial, eigenvectors, and diagonalization. Applications to systems of differential equations and stability analysis.

CSS tips: For time efficiency, use adjugate formula for 3×3 inverses. Always verify determinant calculations as sign errors are common under exam pressure.
keyTakeaways: Use adjugate matrix formula under time constraints.
Check determinant sign to avoid errors.

notes.title: Optimization / Linear Programming
notes.content:
Optimization techniques for finding maxima and minima of functions subject to constraints. CSS occasionally includes basic linear programming problems.

Unconstrained optimization: critical points, second derivative test, and optimization in multiple variables using partial derivatives and Hessian matrix.

Linear programming: graphical method for two variables, identifying feasible regions, corner point evaluation, and interpreting results in context.

CSS approach: Focus on graphical solutions. Plot constraints accurately, identify all intersection points, evaluate objective function at vertices, and clearly state the optimal solution with feasibility check.
keyTakeaways: Plot constraints accurately and enumerate all intersection points.
Evaluate objective function at vertices, mention feasibility.
